project.teaser: The POSEIDON project aims to facilitate the use of e-methanol as e-fuel in shipping by demonstrating innovative solutions along the value chain steps: 1. two complementary CO2 valorisation routes – biogenic CO2 from a biogas plant and industrial plant from a lime plant will...
project.objective: The POSEIDON project aims to facilitate the use of e-methanol as e-fuel in shipping by demonstrating innovative solutions along the value chain steps: 1. two complementary CO2 valorisation routes – biogenic CO2 from a biogas plant and industrial plant from a lime plant will be investigated, 2. A new hybrid TRL7 power-to-e-methanol technology will be built and demonstrated within a test platform allowing to re-create real case studies conditions, 3. The produced e-fuel will be tested in 2- and 4-stroke engines at testing facilities and in a pilot boat in open sea to confirm its applicability. The project will also pave the way for the future implementation of e-methanol value chains in the port areas of Valencia and Thessaloniki. Communities of practice gathering project partners and external local stakeholders interested in the e-fuel transition will be created. These communities will strengthen collaboration, raise awareness of the potentials and benefits of renewable e-fuels, help members share their vision and discuss requirements and challenges. This will be supported by detailed case study assessment: extensive tests will be performed in a Power-to-X test platform and simulations enabling to evaluate environmental, economic and social mid-term to long-term impacts will be carried out. Market studies and business modelling activities will be done to have a clear view of the deployment potential at EU level. To foster market uptake, an EU deployment roadmap and a replication tool allowing external stakeholders to conduct their own pre-feasibility assessment will be developed. A public project guidebook outlining the main key exploitable results and policy recommendations will be published. To achieve all these results, the project will build upon the wide expertise of its 19 partners. The consortium consists of a well-balanced team of industrial partners (8), research partners (5), business support organisations (2), ports (2), an association and a public agency.
project.title: Propulsion Of Ships with E-Methanol In favour of the Decarbonisation Of Naval transport
project.keywords: e-methanol, renewable e-fuel for shipping, e-methanol-based value chains, biogenic and industrial CO2 sources valorisation

article.title: Demonstrating synthetic methanol as fuel for the decarbonisation of shipping

category.title: Project description
category.description: Article: description of linked project written by editorial team

article.title: Discover the EU-funded projects putting the green into waterborne transport
article.teaser: A new CORDIS Synergy Info Pack highlights how projects coming from different countries, sectors and funding programmes are all working towards the same shared goal: making Europe’s waterborne transport sector more sustainable, more efficient and more competitive.

article.title: Bringing synthetic methanol to EU ports
article.teaser: Synthetic methanol, produced via the catalytic reaction of carbon dioxide and hydrogen, has the potential to significantly slash emissions.

article.title: Waterborne transport for a green future
article.teaser: Waterborne transport is vital to Europe’s economy. More than 75 % of European external trade and 35 % of all trade between EU Member States is transported by sea, river, canal or lake. In addition, 350 million passengers alight or disembark from Europe’s ports annually.

result.title: Promotional toolkit and website
result.description: D7.2 is a report that will present all main communication tools and materials including the project corporate identity, the project webpage, the project brochure and roll-up and the main templates to be used for press releases, newsletters and presentations.

result.title: Data Management Plan
result.description: D1.2 is the data management plan. This document document will outline the way data is collected, generated, processed, and stored throughout the lifecycle of the project.This deliverable will also integrate the topic of open access to research data.

result.title: "Mapping of the ""e-methanol as e-fuel for vessels"" value chain"
result.description: "D2.2 is done in task T2.1 of the project. It will be a report describing the ""e-methanol as efuel for vessels” value chain (incl. key stakeholders) and some communication material for the project (internal and external)"

result.title: Summary about the state of the art of the technologies
result.description: D2.4 is done in task T2.4. it will be a synthesis report presenting the main technologies involved in the studies value chain, their current state of maturity and planned evolutions

result.title: Safety Plan
result.description: D1.3 is a safety plan that will be drafted at the start of the project based on inputs from industrial partners and later implemented when the pilot and demonstration activities will start. It should help to ensure maximal safety all along the project.

result.title: COP Framework
result.description: D2.1 is a document presenting the general framework of the Communities of Practices to be set up in Valencia and Thessaloniki. It will include a set of organisational rules and an agenda with planned knowledge exchange, networking and transfer activities to be implemented by local COP members.

result.title: Periodic Reporting for period 1 - POSEIDON (Propulsion Of Ships with E-Methanol In favour of the Decarbonisation Of Naval transport)
result.teaser: The overall goal of the POSEIDON project is to prepare the implementation of local value chains based on e-methanol as fuel for shipping in the ports of Valencia and Thessaloniki. POSEIDON’s main objectives are as follows:1. to build and test an innovative TRL7 e-methanol...

category.title: Report Summary
category.description: Result: Publishable summary (FP7 SESAM) and Summary for publication (H2020 SyGMa)

result.title: Stakeholder decarbonization strategies and challenges
result.description: D2.3 will be a report summarizing the work done in T2.2.Main components of the deliverable will be 1) Analyse the impact of the decarbonization objectives,2) Analyse the main alternative e-fuels (H2, e-ammonia, bio/emethanol...)3) Identify good practices and gaps in the implementation of alternative e-fuels / e-methanol in maritime sector, including security issues 4) Define and evaluate specifications of each stakeholder

category.title: Digital agenda
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development of digital technologies and the digitisation of the economy and society (known as ‘Digital transition’).

category.title: Clean air
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the clean air policy (National Emission Ceiling Directive) aiming to improve ambient air quality and tackle air pollution, to protect the environment and human health.

category.title: Artificial intelligence
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development and deployment of AI-based technologies and solutions. Projects that develop AI-tools as part of their research method are included

category.title: Climate action
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to both mitigating climate change (e.g., contributions to the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions) and adapting to climate change by building resilience (e.g., regarding floods, droughts, spatial planning and better governance, adaptation to changing climate in value chains, etc.).

category.title: Biodiversity
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to Europe’s biodiversity’s path to recovery including species protection, ecosystem conservation, and habitat rehabilitation, all essential for resilience in climate adaptation and addressing ecosystem services but also environmental crime and the health-environment connection.
